unrest}} | arrests = | casualties_label = | notes = }} The '''Tunisian Revolution'''{{cite web|author=Yasmine Ryan |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/01/2011126121815985483.html |title=How Tunisia's revolution began â Features |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/01/15/133592.html |title=Wikileaks might have triggered Tunisâ revolution |publisher=Alarabiya.net |date=|accessdate=13 February 2011}} is an intensive campaign of [[civil resistance]], including a series of street demonstrations taking place in [[Tunisia]]. The events began in December 2010 and led to the ousting of longtime [[President of Tunisia|President]] [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]] in January 2011. Street demonstrations and other unrest have continued to the present day. The demonstrations were precipitated by high [[unemployment]], [[food inflation]], [[corruption]],{{Cite news|last=Spencer |first=Richard |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/tunisia/8258077/Tunisia-riots-US-warns-Middle-East-to-reform-or-be-overthrown.html |title=Tunisia riots: Reform or be overthrown, US tells Arab states amid fresh riots |publisher=Telegraph |date=13 January 2011|accessdate=14 January 2011 |location=London}} a lack of [[freedom of speech]] and other [[political freedom]]s{{cite web|last=Ryan|first=Yasmine |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/01/20111614145839362.html |title=Tunisia's bitter cyberwar |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=|accessdate=14 January 2011}} and poor [[living conditions]]. The protests constituted the most dramatic wave of social and political unrest in Tunisia in three decades{{cite web|url=http://mideast.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2011/01/02/tunisia_s_protest_wave_where_it_comes_from_and_what_it_means_for_ben_ali |title=Tunisia's Protest Wave: Where It Comes From and What It Means for Ben Ali | The Middle East Channel |publisher=Mideast.foreignpolicy.com |date=3 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}}{{Cite news|author=Borger, Julian|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/dec/29/tunisian-president-vows-punish-rioters|title=Tunisian president vows to punish rioters after worst unrest in a decade|date=29 December 2010|work=The Guardian |location=UK|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|accessdate=29 December 2010}} and have resulted in scores of deaths and injuries, most of which were the result of action by police and security forces against demonstrators. The protests were sparked by the [[self-immolation]] of [[Mohamed Bouazizi]] on [[17 December]][http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12120228 Tunisia suicide protester Mohammed Bouazizi dies], BBC, 5 January 2011. and led to the ousting of President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali 28 days later on [[14 January]] 2011, when he officially resigned after fleeing to [[Saudi Arabia]], ending 23 years in power.{{Cite news|author=Wyre Davies |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12195025 |title=BBC News â Tunisia: President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali forced out |publisher=BBC News |date=15 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2011/01/16/18669320.php |title=Uprising in Tunisia: People Power topples Ben Ali regime |publisher=Indybay |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} Labour unions were said to be an integral part of the protests.{{cite web|url=http://www.defenddemocracy.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=11792083&Itemid=347 |title=Trade unions: the revolutionary social network at play in Egypt and Tunisia |publisher=Defenddemocracy.org |date=|accessdate=11 February 2011}} The protests inspired similar [[Arab Spring|actions throughout the Arab world]]; the [[2011 Egyptian revolution|Egyptian revolution]] began after the events in Tunisia and also led to the ousting of Egypt's longtime president [[Hosni Mubarak]] and a [[2011 Libyan civil war|full-scale civil war]] in Libya that led to the ousting of [[Muammar Gaddafi]] after 42 years of his rule; furthermore, uprisings in [[2011 Bahraini uprising|Bahrain]], [[2011 Syrian uprising|Syria]] and [[2011 Yemeni uprising|Yemen]] and major protests have also taken place in [[2011 Algerian protests|Algeria]], [[2011 Jordanian protests|Jordan]], [[2011 Moroccan protests|Morocco]], [[2011 Israeli border demonstrations|Israel's borders]], [[2011 Iraqi protests|Iraq]] and [[Mauritania]]{{Cite news|author=Mohamed Yahya Abdel Wedoud |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/26/mauritania.protest |title='Facebook Generation' continues Mauritania protests |publisher=CNN |date=27 February 2011|accessdate=1 March 2011}} as well as elsewhere in the wider [[North Africa]] and [[Middle East]].{{cite web|author=Name: * |url=http://www.greenleft.org.au/node/41285 |title=Pakistan: 'The spirit of March 15' â pro-democracy movement wins |work=Green Left Weekly |date=20 March 2009 |accessdate=1 March 2011}} Following Ben Ali's departure, a [[state of emergency]] was declared. The Constitutional Court affirmed [[Fouad Mebazaa]] as acting president under Article 57 of the Constitution. A caretaker coalition government was also created, including members of Ben Ali's party, the [[Constitutional Democratic Rally]] (RCD), in key ministries, while including other [[Opposition (politics)|opposition]] figures in other ministries, with elections to take place within 60 days. However, five newly appointed non-RCD ministers resigned almost immediately, and daily street protests in Tunis and other towns around Tunisia continued, demanding that the new government have no RCD members and that the RCD itself be disbanded. On 27 January Prime Minister [[Mohamed Ghannouchi]] reshuffled the government, removing all former RCD members other than himself. On 6 February the new interior minister suspended all party activities of the RCD, citing security reasons.{{Cite news|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jnj3WjlEykmF6gcKD1M335EfPhLg?Id=6fd3d1660cf2420cb7cc0e7c579061fd |agency=The Associated Press|title=Tunisian minister suspends ex-ruling party |publisher=Google |date=|accessdate=8 February 2011}} The party was dissolved, as protesters had demanded, on 9 March 2011.{{cite news| url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2011-03-09-Tunisia_N.htm | work=USA Today | title=Most Popular E-mail Newsletter | date=9 March 2011}} Following further public protests, Ghannouchi himself resigned on 27 February, and [[Beji Caid el Sebsi]] became Prime Minister; two other members of the Interim Government resigned on the following day. On 3 March 2011, the president announced the [[Tunisian Constituent Assembly election, 2011|elections for the Constituent Assembly]], which were held on 23 October 2011 with the Islamist Nahdah Party winning the plurality of seats. ==Naming== In Tunisia and the wider Arab world, the protests and change in government are called the '''Sidi Bouzid Revolt''', derived from [[Sidi Bouzid]], the city where the initial protests began.{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/video/video.php?v=151395198244689 |title=Niet compatibele browser |publisher=Facebook |date=|accessdate=8 February 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://libcom.org/forums/news/protests-spread-tunisia-29122010 |title=The Sidi Bouzid Revolution: Ben Ali flees as protests spread in Tunisia |publisher=libcom.org |date=|accessdate=8 February 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8thJM2nmd_g |title=Revolte Tunisie Sidi bouzid 3 |publisher=YouTube |date=4 January 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011}} In the Western media, these events have been dubbed the '''Jasmine Revolution'''{{cite web|author=Par FrÃ©dÃ©ric Frangeul |url=http://www.europe1.fr/International/D-ou-vient-la-revolution-du-jasmin-375743/ |title=DâoÃ¹ vient la "rÃ©volution du jasmin" ? |publisher=Europe 1 |date=17 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011 |language=french |trans_title=From where does the "Jasmin Revolution" come from?}} ([http://translate.google.com/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.europe1.fr%2FInternational%2FD-ou-vient-la-revolution-du-jasmin-375743%2F Google Translate version]) after Tunisia's national flower and in keeping with the geopolitical nomenclature of "[[color revolutions]]". The name "Jasmine Revolution" originated from Tunisian journalist Zied El-Heni, but it was not widely adopted in Tunisia itself.{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2011/01/17/revolution-du-jasmin-une-expression-qui-ne-fait-pas-l-unanimite_1466871_3212.html/ |title="RÃ©volution du jasmin" : une expression qui ne fait pas l'unanimitÃ© |work=Le Monde |location=Paris |date=17 January 2011 |accessdate=28 January 2011 |language=french |trans_title="Jasmin Revolution": not a universal expression}} ([http://translate.google.fr/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=fr&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=fr&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.lemonde.fr%2Fafrique%2Farticle%2F2011%2F01%2F17%2Frevolution-du-jasmin-une-expression-qui-ne-fait-pas-l-unanimite_1466871_3212.html english translation]) The name adopted in Tunisia was the '''Dignity Revolution''', which is a translation of the Arabic name for the revolution {{lang|ar|Ø«ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙÙØ±Ø§ÙØ©}} (''{{transl|ar|Thawrat al-KarÄmah}}''). Within Tunisia, Ben Ali's rise to power in 1987 was also known as the Jasmine Revolution.{{cite web|author=Olivier Malaponti |url=http://www.mediapart.fr/club/blog/olivier-malaponti/150111/revolution-de-jasmin-0 |title=RÃ©volution de jasmin ? |publisher=Mediapart.fr |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=28 January 2011 |language=french |trans_title=Jasmine Revolution?}} ([http://translate.google.fr/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=fr&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=fr&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mediapart.fr%2Fclub%2Fblog%2Folivier-malaponti%2F150111%2Frevolution-de-jasmin-0 english translation]) The Tunisian revolution has also been considered the first of a series of revolutions named the [[Arab Spring]]. ==Background== President [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]] had ruled Tunisia since 1987 with an iron fist. His government, which had been criticised in the media and amongst NGOs, was supported by the United States and France. As a result, the initial reactions to Ben Ali's abuses by the U.S. and France were muted, and most instances of socio-political protest in the country, when they occurred at all, rarely made major news headlines. Riots in Tunisia were rare{{Cite news|author=|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/10/world/main7233191.shtml |title=Deadly Riots in Tunisia Shut Down Schools |publisher=Cbsnews.com |date=10 January 2011 |accessdate=15 January 2011}} and noteworthy, especially since the country is generally considered to be wealthy and stable as compared to other countries in the region.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011191414183128.html |title=Protesters killed in Tunisia riots |publisher=English.aljazeera.net |date=9 January 2011 |accessdate=15 January 2011}} Any form of protests in the country were previously successfully oppressed and kept silent by the former regime and protesters would be jailed for such actions, as were for example protests by hundreds of unemployed demonstrators in [[Redeyef]] in 2008.{{cite web|author=Jean-Marie LEMAIRE / Rim MATHLOUTI |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110215-reporters-tunisia-redeyef-gafsa-mining-phosphate-accusations-competition-rigged-ben-ali-supporters-protests-journalists |title=Redeyef, the precursor of the Tunisian revolution |publisher=http://www.france24.com |date=15 Februari 2011 |accessdate=15 February 2011}} ''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' also said that Tunisian activists are amongst the most outspoken in its part of the world with various messages of support being posted on ''Twitter'' for Bouazizi.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/2010122063745828931.html |title=Riots reported in Tunisian city â Africa â Al Jazeera English |publisher=English.aljazeera.net |date=20 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} An [[op-ed]] article in the same network said of the action that it was "suicidal protests of despair by Tunisia's youth." It pointed out that the state-controlled [[National Solidarity Fund]] and the [[National Employment Fund]] had traditionally subsidised many goods and services in the country but had started to shift the "burden of providence from state to society" to be funded by the "''[[bidonville]]s''," or [[shanty towns]], around the richer towns and suburbs.{{clarify|date=January 2011}} It also cited the "marginalisation of the agrarian and arid central and southern areas [that] continue[s] unabated."{{cite web|author=Larbi Sadiki |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2010/12/20101227142811755739.html |title=Tunisia: The battle of Sidi Bouzid â Opinion â Al Jazeera English |publisher=English.aljazeera.net |date=27 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} The protests were also called an "uprising" because of "a lethal combination of poverty, unemployment and political repression: three characteristics of most Arab societies."{{cite web|author=Lamis Andoni |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2010/12/20101231161958792947.html |title=The rebirth of Arab activism â Opinion |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=31 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} Another cause for the uprising has been attributed to the inability of the Tunisian government from being able to censor information from reaching the Tunisian people troll, such as information from [[WikiLeaks]] [[Contents of the United States diplomatic cables leak (analysis of individual leaders)#Tunisia|describing rampant corruption]] in the Tunisian government.{{cite web|url=http://strike-the-root.com/internet-and-muhammad-bouazizi |title=The Internet and Muhammad Bouazizi |publisher=Strike-the-root.com |date=19 January 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011}} ===Sidi Bouzid and Mohamed Bouazizi=== Twenty-six year old [[Mohamed Bouazizi]] had been the sole income earner in his extended family of eight. He operated a purportedly unlicensed vegetable cart for seven years in [[Sidi Bouzid]] 190 miles (300 km) south of Tunis. On 17 December 2010 a policewoman confiscated his cart and produce. Bouazizi, who had such an event happen to him before, tried to pay the 10-dinar fine (a day's wages, equivalent to 7USD). In response the policewoman insulted his deceased father. A humiliated Bouazizi then went to the provincial headquarters in an attempt to complain to local municipality officials. He was refused an audience. Without alerting his family, at 11:30 am and within an hour of the initial confrontation, Bouazizi returned to the headquarters, doused himself with a flammable liquid and set himself on fire. Public outrage quickly grew over the incident, leading to protests.{{Cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2043557,00.html | title=Bouazizi: The Man Who Set Himself and Tunisia on Fire | author=Rania Abouzeid | date=Bouzid Friday, 21 Jan. 2011|work=Time Magazine}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.thestar.com/news/world/article/922279--suicide-protest-helped-topple-tunisian-regime | title=Suicide protest helped topple Tunisian regime | location=Toronto | work=The Star | date=14 January 2011}} This immolation and the subsequent heavy-handed response by the police to peaceful marchers caused riots the next day in [[Sidi Bouzid]] that went largely unnoticed, although [[social media]] sites such as Facebook and YouTube featured images of police dispersing youths who attacked shop windows and damaged cars. Bouazizi was subsequently transferred to a hospital near Tunis. In an attempt to quell the unrest President [[Zine el Abidine Ben Ali]] visited Bouazizi in hospital on 28 December 2010. Bouazizi died on 4 January 2011.{{Cite news | url=http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE70408420110105 | title=Tunisian who sparked rare protests dies: relatives -Reuters | publisher=Af.reuters.com | date=5 January 2011 | accessdate=14 January 2011}} ==Protests== Though the bulk of protests followed Bouazizi's self-immolation and led to the departure of Ben Ali, protests also continued after his departure in demanding his party be removed from government. Some more minor protests followed the cabinet reshuffle. ===Early protests=== There were reports of police obstructing demonstrators and using [[tear gas]] on hundreds of young protesters in [[Sidi Bouzid]] in mid-December 2010. The protesters had gathered outside regional government headquarters to demonstrate against the treatment of Mohamed Bouazizi. Coverage of events was limited by Tunisian media. On {{Nowrap|19 December}}, extra police were present on the streets of the city.{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/2010122063745828931.html|title=Images posted on social-network sites show police intervening to halt disturbances ignored by national media|date=20 December 2010|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=20 December 2010}} On 22 December, Lahseen Naji, a protester, responded to "hunger and joblessness" by electrocuting himself after climbing an [[electricity pylon]]. Ramzi Al-Abboudi also killed himself because of financial difficulties arising from a business debt by the country's [[micro-credit]] solidarity programme. On {{Nowrap|24 December}}, Mohamed Ammari was fatally shot in the chest by police in Bouziane. Other protesters were also injured, including Chawki Belhoussine El Hadri, who died later on {{Nowrap|30 December}}.{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/201012317536678834.html|title=A protester dies after being shot by police, as activists criticise government repression of protests|date=31 December 2010|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=31 December 2010}} Police claimed they shot the demonstrators in "self-defence." A "quasi-curfew" was then imposed on the city by police.{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/20101224235824708885.html|title=Protester dies in Tunisia clash: Several wounded in Sidi Bouzid as demonstrations against unemployment turn violent|date=25 December 2010|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=25 December 2010}} Rapper [[El GÃ©nÃ©ral]], whose songs had been adopted by protesters, was arrested on 24 December but released several days later after "an enormous public reaction".{{Cite news|last=Walt |first=Vivienne |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2049456,00.html |title=El GÃ©nÃ©ral and the Rap Anthem of the Mideast Revolution â TIME |work=TIME |date=15 February 2011 |accessdate=1 March 2011}} Violence later increased as Tunisian authorities and residents of [[Sidi Bouzid Governorate]] encountered each other once again. The protests had reached the capital [[Tunis]]{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/2010122682433751904.html|title=Protests continue in Tunisia|date=26 December 2010|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=26 December 2010}} on {{Nowrap|27 December}} with about 1,000 citizens expressing solidarity{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2010/12/20101228182021539319.html |title=Tunisia jobless protests rage â Africa â Al Jazeera English |publisher=English.aljazeera.net |date=28 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} with residents of Sidi Bouzid and calling for jobs. The rally, which was called by independent trade union activists, was stopped by security forces. The protests also spread to [[Sousse]], [[Sfax]] and [[Meknassy]].{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/20101227204853391930.html |title=Job protests escalate in Tunisia â Africa â Al Jazeera English |publisher=English.aljazeera.net |date=28 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} The following day the Tunisian Federation of Labour Unions held another rally in [[Gafsa]] which was also blocked by security forces. At the same time about 300 lawyers held a rally near the government's palace in Tunis.{{cite web|author=Bilal Randeree |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/2010122819724363553.html |title=Tensions flare across Tunisia â Africa â Al Jazeera English |publisher=English.aljazeera.net |date=28 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} Protests continued again on the {{Nowrap|29 December}}. On 30 December, police peacefully broke up a protest in [[Monastir, Tunisia|Monastir]] while using force to disrupt further demonstrations in [[Sbikha]] and [[Chebba]]. Momentum appeared to continue with the protests on {{Nowrap|31 December}} and further demonstrations and public gatherings by lawyers in Tunis and other cities following a call by the Tunisian National Lawyers Order. Mokhtar Trifi, president of the Tunisian Human Rights League (LTDH), said that lawyers across Tunisia had been "savagely beaten." There were also unconfirmed reports of another man attempting to commit suicide in [[El Hamma]].{{Cite news|url=http://24sur24.posterous.com/video-today-a-young-unemployed-man-trying-to|title=video: today a young unemployed man trying to commit a suicide in El Hamma #sidibouzid|date=31 December 2010|work=Nawaat|accessdate=31 December 2010}} On 3 January 2011, protests in [[Thala]] over unemployment and a high [[cost of living]] turned violent. At a demonstration of 250 people, mostly students, in support of the protesters in Sidi Bouzid, police fired tear gas; one canister landed in a local mosque. In response, the protesters were reported to have set fire to tyres and attacked the office of [[Constitutional Democratic Rally]].{{cite web|author=Bilal Randeree |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/201114101752467578.html |title=Violent clashes continue in Tunisia â Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=4 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} Some of the more general protests sought changes in the government's online censorship, where a lot of the media images have been broadcast. Tunisian authorities also allegedly carried out [[phishing]] operations to take control of user passwords and check online criticism. Both state and non-state websites had been hacked.{{cite web|author=Yasmine Ryan |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/01/20111614145839362.html |title=Tunisia's bitter cyberwar â Features |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=6 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} ===Rising elites' support and continuing protests=== On 6 January, 95% of Tunisia's 8,000 lawyers went on strike, according to the chairman of the national [[bar association]]. He said "The strike carries a clear message that we do not accept unjustified attacks on lawyers. We want to strongly protest against the beating of lawyers in the past few days."{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/201116193136690227.html |title=Thousands of Tunisia lawyers strike â Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=6 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} It was reported on the following day that teachers had also joined the strike.{{Cite news|last=Sandels |first=Alexandra |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-tunisia-riots-20110108,0,1279820.story |title=Rioting spreads across Tunisia; unrest also reported in Algeria |work=LA Times |date=8 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} In response to 11 January protests police used riot gear to disperse protesters ransacking buildings, burning tires, setting fire to a bus and burning two cars in the working class suburb of [[Ettadhamen-Mnihla]] in Tunis. The protesters were said to have chanted "We are not afraid, we are not afraid, we are afraid only of God." Military personnel were also deployed in many cities around the country.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2011/01/2011111214716877786.html |title=Tunisia unrest spreads to capital â Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=|accessdate=14 January 2011}} On 12 January, a reporter from the Italian state-owned television broadcaster ''[[RAI]]'' stated that he and his cameraman were beaten with batons by police during a riot in Tunis' central district and that the officers then confiscated their camera.{{Cite news|url=http://www.rai.tv/dl/RaiTV/programmi/media/ContentItem-0ec2c1f9-c6f3-48cd-8166-bc1eca6d13a9-tg3.html|title=Tunisi. Aggredita la troupe del Tg3|date=12 Hanuary 2011|publisher=[[TG3]]|language=Italian|accessdate=12 January 2011}} A night time curfew was also ordered in Tunis after protests and clashes with police.{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12175959 |title=BBC News â Tunisia imposes curfew in Tunis to quell protests |publisher=BBC News |date=13 January 2011|accessdate=14 January 2011}} [[Hizb ut-Tahrir]] also organised protests after [[Friday prayer]] on 14 January to call for re-establishing the Islamic [[caliphate]].{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RNRhq4fFAto&feature=player_embedded |title=Protests organized by Hizb ut-Tahrir calling for the re-establishment of the Islamic caliphate |publisher=Youtube |date=|accessdate=15 January 2011}} A day later, it also organised other protests that went to the [[9 April Prison]] to free political prisoners.{{cite web|url=http://www.alokab.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=56256 |title=Call for re-establishing Caliphate in streets of Tunisia and freeing political prisoners |publisher=Alokab.com |date=|accessdate=15 January 2011}} Also on 14 January (the same day that Ben Ali fled), [[Lucas Dolega]], a photojournalist working for [[European Pressphoto Agency]], was hit in the forehead by a [[tear gas]] canister allegedly fired by the police at short range; he died two days later.Olivier Laurent, "[http://www.bjp-online.com/british-journal-of-photography/news/1937417/french-photographer-dies-tunisia UNESCO, French government call for investigation of Lucas Dolega's death [update 7]]", ''British Journal of Photography,'' 16 January 2011; David Walker, "[http://www.pdnonline.com/pdn/news/Photographer-Dies-of-1505.shtml Photographer dies of injuries in Tunis]", ''Photo District News,'' 18 January 2011; Matthias Bruggmann, et al., "[http://www.visapourlimage.com/news/4967.do Lucas Mebrouk Dolega]", Visa pour l'image, 18 January 2011; Michel Puech, "[http://www.lalettredelaphotographie.com/entries/lucas-dolega-succumbs-to-a-hand-grenade Lucas Dolega succumbs to a hand grenade]", ''La Lettre de la photographie,'' 22 January 2011. All accessed 22 January 2011. On 25 January protesters continued to defy a curfew in Tunis{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/antigovt-protests-intensify-in-tunisia/141431-2.html |title=Anti-govt protests intensify in Tunisia |publisher=IBNLive |date=3 February 2010 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} as reverberations continued around the region. ===Protests against the RCD and new government=== {{See also|Cabinet of Tunisia}} [[Image:Manifestation UGTT anti RCD I.JPG|thumb|A protest by the General Labour Union]] [[Image:RÃ©volution des Jasmains 01.jpg|thumb|Anti-RCD graffiti and vandalism]] Internal and external protests against the presence of [[Constitutional Democratic Rally|RCD]] members in the new government occurred daily starting on 17 January, the day that the new cabinet was announced. Thousands of anti-RCD protesters rallied on 17 January in a protest with relatively little violence between security services and protestors.http://news.sky.com/skynews/Article/201009115896853 Pro-Ben Ali supporters held a rally later in the day.{{citation needed|date=January 2011}} The [[Tunisian General Labour Union]]'s ministers resigned after a day (18 January), citing the presence of RCD ministers in the government as the reason.{{Cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Tunisia announces withdrawal of 3 ministers from unity gov't: TV | date=18 January 2011 | publisher=[[People's Daily Online]] | url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7264930.html |accessdate=20 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vrgMnytL |archivedate=19 January 2011 |deadurl=no }} Mustafa ben Jaafar also refused to take up his post. The interim president and prime minister then left the RCD in a bid to calm protests against the inclusion of RCD members in the government with the PM stating that all members of the national unity government had "clean hands."{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12220862|title=Tunisia: New government leaders quit ruling party | work=BBC News | date=18 January 2011}} On 18 January, street protests against RCD participation in the new government included hundreds of people demonstrating in Tunis, [[Sfax]], [[Gabes]], [[Bizerta]], [[Sousse]] and [[Monastir, Tunisia|Monastir]]. The protests continued on 19 January, with the demand that no "former allies" of Ben Ali should remain in the government, including hundreds of protestors marching in central Tunis and about 30 staging a sit-in near the [[Ministry of the Interior (Tunisia)|Ministry of the Interior]], ignoring a curfew.{{Cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Tunisia leader vows break with past | date=19 January 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011119201252887481.html |accessdate=19 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vrfRSxUe |archivedate=19 January 2011 |deadurl=no }} Protestors also called for the RCD to be disbanded. On 20 January, hundreds of people demonstrated outside of the RCD headquarters in Tunis with the same aims, and protests in other towns around Tunisia were reported.{{Cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Tunisia cabinet to lift party bans | date=20 January 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/201112014107109184.html |accessdate=20 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vstKVA6X |archivedate=20 January 2011 |deadurl=no }} Thousands participated in 21 January protests outside the Interior Ministry.{{Cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title= Protests hit Tunisia amid mourning | date=21 January 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011121104023232257.html |accessdate=21 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vuUSjc1C |archivedate=21 January 2011 |deadurl=no }} [[Zouhair M'Dhaffer]], a close confidant of Ben Ali who was seen as the main architect of the 2002 constitutional reform to lift term limits, resigned from the government on 20 January. All other RCD ministers resigned from the party on the same day. The central committee of the RCD also disbanded on that day.{{cite web|url=http://www.taz.de/1/politik/afrika/artikel/1/ben-alis-partei-ohne-politbuero/ |title=Regierungsbildung in Tunesien: Ben Alis Partei ohne PolitbÃ¼ro |publisher=taz.de |date=|accessdate=26 January 2011}} {{de icon}}{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/01/20/8-Tunisian-leaders-quit-ruling-party/UPI-57211295546906/ |title=8 Tunisian leaders quit ruling party |publisher=UPI.com |date=20 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} Ghannouchi vowed on 21 January 2011 that he would resign after holding transparent and free elections within six months.{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/tunisia_pm_quit_politics/2283958.html |title=Tunisian PM Pledges To Quit Politics After Elections |publisher=Radio Free Europe |date=22 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} On 23 January, thousands of police began to join protests in Tunis over salaries and to assuage blame over political deaths attributed to them during Ben Ali's rule.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1349766/Tunisia-riots-Police-join-protesters-streets.html |title=Tunisia riots: Police join protesters on the streets |publisher=Mail Online |date=24 January 2011|accessdate=26 January 2011 |location=London}} As the country's army chief [[Rachid Ammar]] announced on 24 January 2011 it was on the side of the protesters and would "defend the revolution", rumours emerged that the government would be replaced by a council of "wise men".{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011124163051778391.html |title=Tunisia cabinet to be reshuffled |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=24 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} ====Cabinet reshuffle==== On 27 January 2011 Prime Minister Mohammed Ghannouchi announced that six former members of the RCD party had left the interim government. These included Defence Minister, Foreign Minister, Finance Minister and Interior Minister. Apart from the prime minister, the new government retained just two ministers from Ben Ali's old governmentâthe industry and international cooperation ministersâbut neither of these had been a member of his ruling RCD party. This move was seen as meeting one of the demands of the protestors in Tunisia,{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12302232 |title=Tunisia announces major cabinet reshuffle after protest |publisher=BBC News |date=27 January 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011}} and was supported by the UGTT, which stated its support for the reorganised cabinet.[http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/28/world/africa/28tunisia.html Most Members of Old Cabinet in Tunisia Step Down] New ministers included independent state attorney [[Farhat Rajhi]] as interior minister, retired career diplomat [[Ahmed Ounaies]] as foreign minister and [[Elyes Jouini]] (an economist living in France) as minister delegate to the prime minister in charge of administrative and economic reform.[http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7275560.html Tunisian labor union backs reshuffle of interim government] People's Daily Online, 28 January 2011 ===Anti-Ghannouchi protests=== {{As of|2011|01|28}}, hundreds of people camped beside Mohamed Ghannouchi's office protested against Ghannouchi remaining in the interim government.{{Cite news | first=Lin | last=Noueihed | pages= | language =| title=Tunisia protesters turn government HQ into campsite | date=28 January 2011 | publisher=Reuters | url=http://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFLDE70R13720110128?sp=true |accessdate=29 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w6ESsvhm |archivedate=29 January 2011 |deadurl=no}} A student coordinating food distribution at the protests, Saifeddine Missraoui, stated, "We are not leaving here until Ghannouchi leaves and we get a brand new government." Another protestor, Naim Garbousi from Casbah Media Relations, stated, "The new line-up is a theatre. The symbols of the old regime are left, like Ghannouchi. Why is he insisting on staying? We are 10 million people, there will surely be someone who can replace him." On 2 February 2011, the former interior minister, Rafik Belhaj Kacem also, was arrested by his successor, Farhat Rajhi, concurrently with accusations of former allies of Ben Ali trying to destabilize the state.{{cite web|url=http://dailystar.com.lb/article.asp?edition_id=10&categ_id=2&article_id=124437#axzz1CtomXvJQ |title=Politics â Tunisia interior minister says predecessor arrested |publisher=The Daily Star |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011}} All 24 regional governors were replaced on 3 February 2011.{{Cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/03/us-tunisia-protests-governors-idUSTRE7127X520110203 |title=Tunisia replaces regional governors |publisher=Reuters |date=3 February 2011|accessdate=8 February 2011}} ===Later protests and developments=== On 4 February, Sidi Bouzid was again the scene of protests despite the arrests of two security forces personnel for deaths of two. Several hundred people turned up at the local police station as a result of medical staff at a local hospital saying they found signs of burning on the victims' bodies. On 5 February, protesters in [[El Kef]] called for the local police chief Khaled Ghazouani to be sacked for abusing his authority. Protesters threw stones and small firebombs as well as burned two cars, one of which was a police vehicle. Police first responded with tear gas and then fired on the protesters in which two people were killed immediately and two died in hospital, 15 others were also wounded. The region's [[prefect]] Mohamed Najib Tlijali called for calm{{cite web|author=By BOUAZZA BEN BOUAZZA Associated Press |url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ap/top/all/7414844.html |title=Tunisian police fire on crowd, killing 2 | Top AP Stories | Chron.com â Houston Chronicle |work=Houston Chronicle |date=|accessdate=8 February 2011}} as the police chief was arrested. The former ruling RCD's activities were suspended on 6 February 2011 to prevent a breakdown in state security, with an order for dissolution of the party pending.{{Cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/06/tunisia-protests-party-idUSLDE7150FS20110206 |title=Tunisia suspends activities of ex-ruling party |publisher=Reuters |date=6 February 2011|accessdate=8 February 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.newstime.co.za/WorldNews/Ben_Ali%E2%80%99s_RCD_Party_Banned_By_Interim_Tunisian_Government/20217/ |title=Ben Aliâs RCD Party Banned By Interim Tunisian Government : NewsTime : World News |publisher=NewsTime |date=|accessdate=11 February 2011}} Protests flared up again on 19 February and 20 February, with 40,000 protesters demanding a new interim government completely free of any people associated with the old regime. Protesters also demanded a parliamentary system of government instead of the current presidential one.{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/tunisia-protests-resume-for-second-straight-day-amid-uncertainty-of-future-government-1.344628 |title=Tunisia protests resume for second straight day amid uncertainty of future government â Haaretz Daily Newspaper | Israel News |work=Haaretz |location=Israel |date=18 January 2011 |accessdate=1 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7294037.html |title=Thousands call for setting up parliamentary system in Tunisia â People's Daily Online |publisher=English.people.com.cn |date=21 February 2011 |accessdate=1 March 2011}} As a date was announced for an [[Tunisian general election, 2011|election]] in mid-July 2011, more than 100,000 protesters continued to demand the removal of Ghannouchi as interim prime minister.{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/167012.html |title=PressTV - Tunisians want PM Ghannouchi gone |publisher=Presstv.ir |date=25 February 2011 |accessdate=1 March 2011}} After an even larger rally on 27 February 2011, Ghannouchi resigned, saying: "After having taken more than one week of thinking, I became convinced, and my family shared my conviction, and decided to resign. It is not fleeing my responsibilities; I have been shouldering my responsibilities since 14 January [when Mr Ben Ali fled]," and "I am not ready to be the person who takes decisions that would end up causing casualties. This resignation will serve Tunisia, and the revolution and the future of Tunisia."{{Cite news| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12591445 | title = Tunisian PM Mohammed Ghannouchi resigns over protests | publisher=BBC | date=27 February 2011}}{{Cite news| title = Tunisian prime minister resigns amid renewed protests | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/27/tunisia.government/ | publisher=CNN | date=1 April 2011}} He was replaced by [[Beji Caid el Sebsi]]. The following day two more ministers resigned (industry minister [[Afif Chelbi]] and international co-operation minister [[Mohamed Nouri Jouini]]) amid continuing protests for the entire interim government to resign, with the UGTT calling for an elected constituent assembly to write a new constitution.{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/c98b8226-4382-11e0-8f0d-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1FM20ZK98 |title=/ Middle East & North Africa - Two more Tunisian ministers resign |work=Financial Times |date=|accessdate=1 March 2011}} The [[Ennahda Movement]] was legalised on 1 March 2011.http://www.zawya.com/story.cfm/sidZW20110301000110 The resignations of the Minister for Higher Education and Scientific Research [[Ahmed Brahim (politician)|Ahmed Brahim]]{{cite web|url=http://www.forexpros.com/news/general-news/tunisia-minister-of-higher-education-ahmed-brahim-tells-reuters-198606 |title=Tunisia Minister Of Higher Education Ahmed Brahim Tells Reuters By Reuters |publisher=Forexpros.com |date=|accessdate=1 March 2011}} and the Minister of Local Development [[Ahmed Nejib Chebbi]] was officially announced by the [[Tunis Afrique Presse]] (TAP) agency. A private radio broadcaster [[Shems FM]] also reported that the Minister of Economic Reform [[Elyes Jouini]] had resigned as well.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/03/201131134458332348.html |title=Tunisian ministers continue to quit |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2011-03-01 |accessdate=2011-06-22}} On 3 March 2011, the president announced that [[Tunisian Constituent Assembly election, 2011|elections to a Constituent Assembly]] would be held on 24 July 2011; this likely means that [[Tunisian general election, 2011|general elections]] will be postponed to a later date.{{cite web|url=http://www.focus-fen.net/index.php?id=n243650 |title=Tunisia to elect constituent assembly on 24 July, says president - FOCUS Information Agency |publisher=Focus-fen.net |date= |accessdate=2011-06-22}} This fulfilled a central demand of protesters.{{cite web|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7308013.html |title=Tunisia's interim president announces election of constitutional council - People's Daily Online |publisher=English.people.com.cn |date=2011-03-04 |accessdate=2011-06-22}} On 7 March 2011, the interim government announced that the secret police would be dissolved, which were one of the hallmarks of Ben Ali's rule.{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12669461 | work=BBC News | title=Tunisia interim leaders dissolve secret police agency | date=7 March 2011}} On 9 March 2011, the RCD was dissolved by court order. ===Refugees=== In mid-February, about 4,000 mostly Tunisian refugees landed on the Italian island of [[Lampedusa]], causing the authorities to declare a state of emergency{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/02/20112122328974957.html |title=Italy declares migrant emergency â Europe |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=|accessdate=13 February 2011}} that would allow for federal aid to the island. Interior Minister [[Roberto Maroni]] accused the EU of not doing enough to curb immigration and asked them to do more.{{cite web|author=AGI â Agenzia Giornalistica Italia |url=http://www.agi.it/english-version/world/elenco-notizie/201102112043-pol-ren1094-tunisia_italy_asks_eu_to_start_frontex_mission |title=Agi News On â Tunisia: Italy Asks Eu To Start Frontex Mission |publisher=Agi.it |date=|accessdate=13 February 2011}} He said that the "Tunisian system was 'collapsing'" and that he would "ask the Tunisian Foreign Ministry for permission for our authorities to intervene to stop the flow in Tunisia," suggesting Italian troops would be on Tunisian soil.{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-12443740 |title=BBC News â Italy 'to deploy police to Tunisia' to tackle migration |publisher=BBC News |date=13 February 2011|accessdate=13 February 2011}} He called the event a "biblical exodus." The comments started a row between the two countries with the Tunisian Foreign Ministry saying it was ready to work with Italy and others but that it "categorically rejects any interference in its internal affairs or any infringement of its sovereignty." In response, Italy's Foreign Minister [[Franco Frattini]] said that both countries share a "common interest" to halt the immigration, while he also offered "logistical help in terms of police and equipment. Until now the system of patrolling the coasts of Northern Africa has worked and we want to re-establish the technique, which had reduced illegal immigration to zero until a month ago." Tunisia then said that it had troops patrolling southern fishing ports and that checkpoints had been erected in coastal towns. By 14 February, at least 2,000 refugees had been sent to [[Sicily]] with the other 2,000 [[quarantine]]d at a re-opened holding centre. On 2 March about 350 more people arrived on the island. In response Italy declared a humanitarian emergency.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/03/201132135258524383.html |title=Tunisian migrants land in Italy |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2011-03-02 |accessdate=2011-06-22}} The [[International Organisation for Migration]] said that no new boats had been spotted. The EU's Catherine Ashton was on a visit to Tunisia to discuss the issue. German Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] said that "not everyone who does not want to be in Tunisia can come to Europe. Rather, we need to talk to each other how we can strengthen the rule of law in Tunisia again and whether Europe can be of help."{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2011/02/2011214133653175984.html |title=Italy struggles with Tunisia influx â Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=20 February 2011}} ==Arrests== Reports indicate that several [[weblog]]gers and the rapper [[Hamada Ben Aoun]]{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/video/video.php?v=129701343760262&oid=153793954645919&comments |title=Facebook video |publisher=Facebook.com |date=|accessdate=8 February 2011}}{{Better source|date=February 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.myvidster.com/video/908155/el_gnral_the_voice_of_Tunisia_english_subtitles |title=el gÃ©nÃ©ral, the voice of Tunisia, english subtitles |publisher=Myvidster.com |date=|accessdate=26 January 2011}} were arrested, but that the rapper and some of the bloggers were later released.{{Cite news|last=Lewis |first=Aidan |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12180954 |title=Tunisia protests: Cyber war mirrors unrest on streets |publisher=BBC News |date=14 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} [[Reporters Without Borders]] said the arrest of at least six bloggers and activists, who had either been arrested or had disappeared across Tunisia, was brought to their attention and that there were "probably" others.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/20111718360234492.html |title=Tunisia arrests bloggers and rapper|publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=7 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} [[Tunisian Pirate Party]] activists Slah Eddine Kchouk, [[Slim Amamou]] (later released,{{cite web|url=http://jilliancyork.com/2011/01/06/tunisian-blogger-slim-amamou-arrested|title=Tunisian Blogger Slim Amamou Arrested}}{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/slim404 |title=Slim Amamou (slim404) on Twitter |publisher=Twitter |date=|accessdate=26 January 2011}} and eventually appointed Secretary of State for Sport and Youth by the incoming government){{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/9363808.stm |title=Turmoil in Tunisia: As it happened on Monday |publisher=BBC News |date=17 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} and [[Azyz Amamy]] had been reported to have had "disappeared" as no news was heard about them.{{cite web|url=http://christianengstrom.wordpress.com/2011/01/09/tunisia-arrests-pirate-party-bloggers/ |title=Tunisia arrests Pirate Party bloggers |publisher=Christianengstrom.wordpress.com |date=23 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://torrentfreak.com/pirate-party-members-arrested-in-tunisian-censorship-revolt-110108/ |title=Pirate Party Members arrested |publisher=Torrentfreak.com |date=8 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}}{{dubious|date=January 2011}} [[Hamma Hammami]], the leader of the banned [[Tunisian Workers' Communist Party]] and a prominent critic of Ben Ali, was arrested on 12 January, though he was released two days later.[http://www.expatica.com/fr/news/french-news/tunisia-releases-opposition-communist-leader-party_123299.html Tunisia releases opposition Communist leader: party] Expatica, 14 January 2011 ==Domestic political response== During a national television broadcast on {{Nowrap|28 December}}, [[List of Presidents of Tunisia|President]] [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]] criticised people for their protests calling the perpetrators "extremists and mercenaries" and warned of "firm" punishment. He also accused "certain foreign television channels of broadcasting false allegations without verification, based on dramatisation, fermentation and deformation by media hostile to Tunisia."{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/2010122823238574209.html|title=Tunisia president warns protesters|date=28 December 2010|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=28 December 2010}} His remarks were ignored and the protests continued.{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/12/20101229122733122341.html|title=Tunisia struggles to end protests|date=29 December 2010|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=29 December 2010}} On 29 December, Zine El Abidine Ben Ali shuffled his cabinet to remove his communications minister [[Oussama Romdhani]], while also announcing changes to the trade and handicrafts, religious affairs, communication and youth portfolios.{{Cite news|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2010/12/29/131431.html|title=Tunisian president removes ministers after protests|date=29 December 2010|work=[[Al Arabiya]]|accessdate=29 December 2010}} The next day he also announced the dismissal of the governors of Sidi Bouzid, [[Jendouba Governorate|Jendouba]] and [[Zaghouan Governorate|Zaghouan]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.rnw.nl/africa/bulletin/more-heads-roll-tunisian-social-crisis|title=More heads roll in Tunisian social crisis|date=30 December 2010|work=[[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]]|accessdate=30 December 2010}} In January 2011, Ben Ali said 300,000 new jobs would be created, though he did not clarify what that meant. However, he also described the protests as "the work of masked gangs that attacked at night government buildings and even civilians inside their homes in a terrorist act that cannot be overlooked." [[Ahmed Najib Chebbi]], the leader of the [[Progressive Democratic Party (Tunisia)|Progressive Democratic Party]], then said that despite official claims of police firing in self-defense "the demonstrations were non-violent and the youths were claiming their rights to jobs" and that "the funeral processions [for those killed on 9 January] turned into demonstrations, and the police fired [at] the youths who were at these .. processions." He then criticised Ben Ali's comments as the protesters were "claiming their civil rights, and there is no terrorist act...no religious slogans," while accusing Ben Ali of "looking for scapegoats." He further criticised the additional jobs offered as mere "promises."{{cite web|author=Bilal Randeree |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/201111016239214548.html |title=Tunisian leader promises new jobs â Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=10 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} On 10 January, the government announced the indefinite closure of all schools and universities in order to quell the unrest.{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12155670 |title=BBC News â Tunisia closes schools and universities following riots |publisher=BBC News |date=10 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} Days before departing office, Ben Ali announced that he would not change the [[Constitution of Tunisia|present constitution]], which was read as, in effect, promising to step down in 2014 due to his age.{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110113-tunisia-protests-ben-ali-speech-will-not-seek-reelection |title=Ben Ali rules out 'presidency for life' as chaos spreads| publisher=France 24| date=13 January 2011}} On 26 January, after Ben Ali left the country, international arrest warrants were issued for him, his wife and several other members of his family.{{Cite news|author=CNN Wire Staff |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/26/tunisia.warrant/ |title=Tunisia issues warrant for ousted leader, family members |publisher=CNN |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} The Interior Ministry replaced 34 top-level security officials in a bid to bring change to the police, security services and spies that were a part of Ben Ali's security infrastructure. The interim [[head of state]] Fouad Mebazaa promised a national dialogue to address protester demands.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121210345525985.html |title=Middle East rulers make concessions â Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=|accessdate=13 February 2011}} Foreign minister [[Ahmed Ounaies]] resigned on 13 February over controversial praise he gave to French Foreign Minister [[Michele Alliot-Marie]], who was being criticised for her ties to Ben Ali.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/02/201121314913447933.html |title=Tunisian foreign minister resigns |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=13 February 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2011}} [[Mouldi Kefi]] became the new foreign minister on 21 February.{{cite web|url=http://www.shemsfm.net/actualite/actualites_tunisie-news/mouldi-kefi-est-le-nouveau-ministre-des-affaires-etrangeres/12 |title=Mouldi Kefi est le nouveau Ministre des Affaires EtrangÃ¨res |publisher=Shemsfm.net |date=|accessdate=1 March 2011}} ===President Ben Ali's ousting=== [[Image:Tunisia Unrest - VOA - Tunis 14 Jan 2011 (3).jpg|thumb|Translation from French: Ben Ali Get out]] [[File:Zabadehors.JPG|thumb|Translation from French: Ben Ali out]] The Tunisian military brought about the 14 Jan. ousting of President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali when they chased off his security forces. After Ben Ali was forced into exile, Army Commander Rashid Ammar pledged to "protect the revolution."{{cite web|last=Shahine |first=Alaa |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-31/egypt-s-military-leaders-tighten-six-decade-government-grip-amid-protests.html |title=Egypt's Military Tightens Control Over Regime |publisher=Bloomberg |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011}} On 14 January, [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali|Ben Ali]] dissolved his government and declared a [[state of emergency]]. Officials said the reason for the emergency declaration was to protect Tunisians and their property. People were also barred from gathering in groups of more than three, otherwise courting arrest or being shot if they tried to run away.{{Cite news|author=From Rima Maktabi, CNN |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/14/tunisia.protests/ |title=Tunisian PM takes over as interim president as Ben Ali flees - CNN.com |publisher=CNN |date=15 January 2011|accessdate=14 January 2011}}{{cite web|author=Post a Job |url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-01-14/tunisia-in-state-of-emergency-president-to-dissolve-parliament.html |title=Tunisia President Hands Power to Prime Minister |work=BusinessWeek |date=8 December 2009 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} Ben Ali also called for an election within six months to defuse demonstrations aimed at forcing him out.{{cite news|author=Peter Walker and agencies |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/14/tunisian-president-dismisses-government-violence |title=Tunisian president declares state of emergency and sacks government |publisher=Guardian |date= 14 January 2011|accessdate=2011-10-28 |location=London}} ''[[France24]]'' also said the military took control of the airport and closed the country's [[airspace]].{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110114-tunisia-prime-minister-assumes-power-amid-reports-president-ben-ali-has-left/ |title=Prime minister takes over as Ben Ali flees Tunisian turmoil |publisher=France24 |date=|accessdate=15 January 2011}} On the same day, Ben Ali fled the country for [[Malta]] under [[Libya]]n protection{{cite web|last=Laghmari |first=Jihen |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-13/tunisia-president-to-stand-down-in-2014-slash-prices-amid-riots.html |title=Tunisia President Hands Power to Prime Minister |publisher=Bloomberg |date=13 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} and landed in [[Jeddah]], Saudi Arabia, after France rejected a request for the plane to land on its territory. Prime Minister [[Mohamed Ghannouchi]] then briefly took over as acting president.{{cite web|last=Ganley |first=Elaine |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/A/AF_TUNISIA_RIOTS?SITE=CTDAN&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT |title=NewsTimes.com â The Latest |publisher=Hosted.ap.org |date=|accessdate=14 January 2011}} Saudi Arabia cited "exceptional circumstances" for their heavily criticised decision to give him asylum saying it was also "in support of the security and stability of their country." The Saudi decision was "not out of sympathy" for Ben Ali (who had long fought against [[Islamism|Islamists]] in Tunisia). Saudi Arabia demanded Ben Ali remain "out of politics" as a condition for accepting him.{{Cite news|title=Ben Ali gets refuge in Saudi Arabia|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201111652129710582.html|publisher=Al Jazeera English}} On the morning of 15 January, Tunisian state TV announced that Ben Ali had officially resigned his position and Ghannouchi had handed power over to parliamentary speaker [[Fouad Mebazaa]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/16/world/africa/16tunis.html|title=New Change of Power Raises Questions in Tunisia|author=David D. Kirkpatrick | work=The New York Times|date=15 January 2011}} This was done after the head of Tunisia's Constitutional Court, Fethi Abdennadher, declared that Ben Ali had left for good, Ghannouchi did not have right to power and Mebazaa would be given 60 days to organise new [[Tunisian parliamentary election, 2011|election]].http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110115/D9KOQ2B01.html Mebazaa said it was in the country's best interest to form a [[National Unity government]].http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110115/D9KOQT000.html [[INTERPOL]] confirmed that its National Central Bureau (NCB) in Tunis has issued a global alert via INTERPOL's international network to seek the location and arrest of former Tunisian President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali and six of his relatives.{{cite web|author=Interpol |url=http://www.interpol.int/Public/ICPO/PressReleases/PR2011/PR007.asp |title=Interpol Press Release |publisher=Interpol.int |date=|accessdate=8 February 2011}} A commission to reform the constitution and current law in general has been set up under [[Yadh Ben Achour]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2011/01/17/en-tunisie-un-nouvel-executif-en-marche_1466513_3212.html |title=En Tunisie, le nouvel exÃ©cutif prÃ©pare les Ã©lections |work=Le Monde |location=Paris |date=17 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} There have also been calls by the opposition to delay the elections and hold them in six or seven months and with international supervision.{{cite web|url=http://www.lepoint.fr/fil-info-reuters/trois-chefs-de-l-opposition-dans-le-gouvernement-tunisien-16-01-2011-129922_240.php |title=Trois chefs de l'opposition dans le gouvernement tunisien, actualitÃ© Reuters |publisher=Le Point |date=17 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} ===Immediate aftermath=== [[Image:Ordre Armee tunisienne 2011.JPG|thumb|Tunisian soldiers serving as [[gendarmarie|gendarmes]]]] [[Image:RÃ©volution des Jasmins 05.jpg|thumb|A Tunisian army tank deployed in front of the St. Vincent de Paul Cathedral in Tunis]] Following Ben Ali's departure, violence and looting continued and the national army was reported to be extensively deployed in Tunisia. The identity of the perpetrators has not been determined. A high official of the Tunisian military, however, also stated that elements loyal to former President Ben Ali have deployed across the country.{{Cite news|journal=Le Monde|title=Paris prÃªt Ã  bloquer les comptes du clan Ben Ali en France|date=15 January 2011|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2011/01/15/l-elysee-dit-surveiller-les-avoirs-financiers-tunisiens-en-france_1466190_3212.html#ens_id=1245377|accessdate=15 January 2011|quote=L'identitÃ© de ces hommes n'a pas Ã©tÃ© Ã©tablie, mais un haut responsable militaire, s'exprimant sous couvert de l'anonymat, a affirmÃ© que des Ã©lÃ©ments loyaux au prÃ©sident Ben Ali se dÃ©ployaient Ã  travers la Tunisie.}} The capital's main train station was also torched.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011115135844457245.html |title=Army on streets amid Tunisia unrest |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} A prison director in [[Mahdia]] freed about 1,000 inmates following a prison rebellion that left 5 people dead.{{Cite news|author=Ap / Elaine Ganley And Bouazza Ben Bouazza |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2042712,00.html |title=1,000 Inmates Freed Amid Tunisia Unrest |work=TIME |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} Many other prisons also had jail breaks or raids from external groups to force prisoner releases, some suspected to be aided by prison guards. General pandemonium was said{{By whom|date=February 2011}} to have occurred in Tunisia as residents who were running out of necessary food supplies had armed themselves and barricaded their homes, even to the extent of having formed armed neighbourhood watches. ''Al Jazeera'''s correspondent said there were apparently three different armed groups: the police (250,000 people of the country's population were supposedly part of the police force), security forces from the Interior Ministry, and irregular militias supportive of Ben Ali who were vying for control.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/20111167140864373.html |title=Tunisia gripped by uncertainty |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} Gun battles took place near the Presidential Palace between the Tunisian army and elements of security organs loyal to the former regime after Ali Seriati, head of presidential security, was arrested and accused of threatening state security by fomenting violence.{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12202283 |title=Tunis gun battles erupt after Ben Ali aide arrested |publisher=BBC News |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} The Tunisian army was reportedly struggling to assert control.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2011/01/2011116102520122416.html |title=Tunisia army tries to restore calm |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} Gunfire continued in Tunis and Carthage as security services struggled to maintain law and order.http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/2011116191514949896.html The most immediate result of the protests was seen in increased [[internet freedom]]s.{{cite web|author=Jillian C. York |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/01/201111410250537313.html |title=Tunisia's taste of internet freedom â Opinion |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=|accessdate=15 January 2011}} While commentators were divided about the extent to which the internet contributed to the ousting of Ben Ali from power,Luke Alnutt (2012)[http://www.rferl.org/content/tunisia_can_we_please_stop_talking_about_twitter_revolutions/2277052.html TANGLED WEB Tunisia: Can We Please Stop Talking About 'Twitter Revolutions'?]. Retrieved 15 January 2011.{{cite web|author=by zeynep |url=http://technosociology.org/?p=263 |title=Tunisia, Twitter, Aristotle, Social Media and Final and Efficient Causes |publisher=technosociology |date=21 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.opednews.com/articles/How-Facebook-Helped-Fell-t-by-Tawnia-Sanford-Amm-110115-765.html|title=How Facebook Helped Fell the 23-Year-Old-Tunisian Dictatorship and Fuel the Jasmine Revolution}} Facebook remained accessible to roughly 20% of the population throughout the crisis{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2011-01-15/tunisa-protests-the-facebook-revolution |title=Tunisia Protests: The Facebook Revolution |publisher=The Daily Beast |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} whilst its passwords were hacked by a country-wide [[man-in-the-middle attack]],{{cite web|url=http://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2011/01/the-inside-story-of-how-facebook-responded-to-tunisian-hacks/70044/ |title=The Inside Story of How Facebook Responded to Tunisian Hacks |publisher=The Atlantic |date=24 January 2011 |first=Alexis |last=Madrigal |accessdate=26 January 2011}} YouTube and [[DailyMotion]] became available after Ben Ali's ouster,{{cite web|author=Jillian C. York |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/01/201111410250537313.html |title=Tunisia's taste of internet freedom |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=14 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} and the [[Tor (anonymity network)|''Tor'' anonymity network]] reported a surge of traffic from Tunisia.{{cite web|url=https://blog.torproject.org/blog/update-tor-usage-tunisia |title=Update on Tor usage in Tunisia |publisher=The Tor Blog |date=|accessdate=26 January 2011}} ==Post-Ben Ali governments== {{See|Government of Mohamed Ghannouchi}} The unity government announced on 17 January included twelve members of the ruling RCD, the leaders of three opposition parties ([[Mustapha Ben Jafar]] from the [[Democratic Forum for Labour and Liberties]], [[Ahmed Ibrahim]] of the [[Ettajdid Movement]] and [[Ahmed Najib Chebbi]] of the [[Progressive Democratic Party (Tunisia)|Progressive Democratic Party]]),{{cite web|url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90031186?Tunisian%20prime%20minister%20invites%20all%20political%20parties%20to%20form%20unity%20government|title=Tunisian prime minister invites all political parties to form unity government}} three representatives from the [[Tunisian General Labour Union]] (UGTT) and representatives of civil society (including prominent blogger [[Slim Amamou]]). Just one day after the formation of the temporary government the three members of the UGTT as well as Mustapha Ben Jafaar, head of the FTDL opposition party quit saying that they had "no confidence" in a government that still featured members of the RCD party that ruled under Ben Ali.Angelique Chrisafis, [http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/18/tunisia-caretaker-government-ministers-quit "Tunisia's caretaker government in peril as four ministers quit,"] ''The Guardian'' (18-01-2011). [retrieved 22-01-2011]David D. Kirkpatrick, [http://www.heraldtribune.com/article/20110122/znyt03/101223013 "Protesters Say Ruling Party in Tunisia Must Dissolve,"] ''Herald Tribune'' (21-01-2011). [retrieved 22-01-2011] The ''[[Times of Malta]]'' suggested that three notable movements not included in the national unity government were the banned [[Ennahda Movement]], the communist [[Tunisian Workers' Communist Party]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12225856|title=Could Tunisian opposition groups re-ignite the revolt?|author=Larbi Sadiki | work=BBC News|date=19 January 2011}} and the secular reformist [[Congress for the Republic]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12214649|title=Tunisia: Key players | work=BBC News | date=27 February 2011}} It was unclear whether the ban on these parties and the ban on Hizb ut-Tahrir would be lifted until 12 March 2011, when they were declared as banned again.{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gYSo-aNuYiO1QSK1E6-18ALIC6JQ?docId=CNG.4caadd27ed3929bab816dcdc2d6a2705.841 |title=Tunisian Ministry of Interior denies permit for 5 parties including Hizb ut-Tahrir |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-22}} The Ennahda Movement on the other hand, got a permit.http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20110118/world-news/exiled-opposition-chief-returns-to-tunisiahttp://www.france24.com/en/20110118-tunisia-president-prime-minister-quit-RDC-ruling-party-retain-posts On 20 January 2011, the new government announced in its first sitting that all banned parties would be legalised and that all political prisoners would be freed.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/20111215365840302.html |title=Tunisia mourns unrest victims |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=21 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} ;Political actions On 7 February 2011 Tunisia's Defense Ministry called up recently retired troops as the country still struggles to contain unrest. Soldiers, retired within the last five years, as well as those who recently carried out their mandatory military service, are being asked to report for duty.{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110207/D9L853V00.html |title=Tunisia calls up reserve troops amid unrest |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date=|accessdate=8 February 2011}} First steps were taken on a bill that would give the interim president, Fouad Mebazaa, emergency powers, allowing him to bypass the RCD-dominated parliament.{{cite web|last=Bouderbala |first=Sofia |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5juBHIGNP6tw4F6SZgHqEqUv_71IA?docId=CNG.f633c1f93ead7c4ea82895634cdfeeaf.481 |title=AFP: Tunisian lawmakers approve emergency powers |publisher=Google |date=|accessdate=8 February 2011}} An agreement between the interim government and the [[UGTT]] on nomination of new governors was reached on 8 February 2011.{{cite web|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7281826.html |title=Tunisian gov't reaches agreement with labor union on governor nomination â People's Daily Online |publisher=English.people.com.cn |date=|accessdate=11 February 2011}} The bill to grant [[Fouad Mebazaa]] emergency powers was passed on 9 February. He stated that all banned parties would be legalised within days.{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12410704 |title=Tunisia senate agrees to widen presidential powers |publisher=BBC News |date=9 February 2011|accessdate=11 February 2011}} The bill also allows Mebazaa to ratify international human rights treaties without parliament;{{cite web|author=Kommentar posten |url=http://derstandard.at/1297216065664/Praesident-gestaerkt-Tunesiens-Parlament-entmachtet-sich |title=Tunesiens Parlament entmachtet sich â Tunesien â derStandard.at " International |publisher=Derstandard.at |date=|accessdate=11 February 2011}} he has previously stated Tunisia would accede to the [[International Convention for the Protection of All Persons from Enforced Disappearance]], the [[Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court|Rome Statute]] of the [[International Criminal Court]], the [[Optional Protocol to the Convention against Torture and other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment]], and the [[First Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights|First]] and [[Second Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]] (which would mean abolishing the death penalty).{{cite web|url=http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files_156/tunisia_286/france-and-tunisia_5166/political-relations_5169/tunisia-endorsement-of-major-international-commitments-relating-to-human-rights-02.02.11_14974.html |title=France-Diplomatie |publisher=Diplomatie.gouv.fr |date=|accessdate=11 February 2011}} Further protests caused numerous fatalities, and on 27 Feb Prime Minister Mohamed Ghannouchi resigned. On 9 March, a court in Tunis announced the dissolution of the former ruling party, the Rally for Constitutional Democracy (RCD), and the liquidation of its assets and funds, but the party said it would appeal the decision. On 14 April 2011, it was announced that Ben Ali would face 18 charges, including voluntary manslaughter and drug-trafficking. His family and former ministers are also going to face 26 further charges.{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13082028 | work=BBC News | title=Tunisia's former President Ben Ali faces 18 charges | date=14 April 2011}} ==Reactions== ===Domestic=== Prime Minister Mohamed Ghannouchi's government asked Saudi Arabia to extradite Ben Ali saying that "following a new batch of charges against the ousted president regarding his involvement in several serious crimes aimed at perpetrating and inciting voluntary homicide and sowing discord between the citizens of the same country by pushing them to kill one another."{{cite web |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5g1FkUvosmNAcR0vpAT99VQg3f_tg?docId=CNG.2fa97f53bfcdc1875eb8f281d95222b2.601 |title=AFP: Tunisia asks Saudi Arabia to extradite Ben Ali |publisher=Google |date=20 February 2011 |accessdate=1 March 2011}} Reports emerged on 18 February 2011 that Ben Ali had had a stroke and was gravely ill.{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12497988 |title=Tunisia's Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali 'seriously ill' |publisher=BBC News |date=17 February 2011|accessdate=20 February 2011}} Plans for a general amnesty were also announced on that day.{{cite web|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90855/7293137.html |title=Tunisian PM says general amnesty to be proclaimed this week â People's Daily Online |publisher=English.people.com.cn |date=19 February 2011 |accessdate=1 March 2011}} ;Other The national stock market is [[Bourse de Tunis|TUNINDEX]], fell on 12 January for a three consecutive day loss of 9.3%.{{cite web|url=http://www.africanmanager.com/site_eng/detail_article.php?art_id=16151 |title=Tunisia: further decline in Tunis stock market for third consecutive day |publisher=Africanmanager.com |date=|accessdate=15 January 2011}} Following the curfew in Tunis, the market index again fell 3.8% as cost to protect against a sovereign default in [[credit default swaps]] rose to its highest level in almost two years.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-13/tunisia-stocks-slump-to-year-low-as-troops-deployed-to-tunis-amid-curfew.html|title=Tunisia Stocks Slump to Year-Low as Troops Deployed to Tunis Amid Curfew|author=Ahmed Namatalla}}{{Cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/tunisiaNews/idAFLDE70C11W20110113|title=Tunisia c.bank CDS at 18-mth high of 154 bps-CMA | work=Reuters | date=13 January 2011}} Following Ghanoucchi and two other Ben Ali-era ministers resigning the bourse was again suspended.{{Cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/28/tunisia-government-jouini-idUSLDE71R2G620110228 |title=Second Tunisian minister quits, bourse suspended |publisher=Reuters |date=28 February 2011|accessdate=1 March 2011}} ===International and non-state=== {{main|International reactions to the Tunisian revolution}} [[Image:Manif tunisie Nantes.JPG|thumb|Demonstration in support of the Tunisian protests in [[Nantes]], France, 15 January 2011.]] Many governments and supranational organisations expressed concerns over use of force against protesters. [[France]], the former colonial power of Tunisia, was one of just a few states that expressed strong support for the Ben Ali government prior to its ouster, though protests were held in solidarity with Tunisia in several French cities and the [[French Socialist Party]] voiced support for the popular revolution. ===Media and punditry=== The protests and resultant political crisis have generally been called the ''Jasmine Revolution'' only in the foreign media.{{Cite news|first=Mona |last=Eltahawy |title=Tunisia's Jasmine Revolution |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/14/AR2011011405084.html|work=Washington Post |publisher=|date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=15 January 2011}}{{Cite news|first=|last=|title=Tunisia's 'Jasmine Revolution' jolts Arab world|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/2/8/3955/World/Region/Tunisias-Jasmine-Revolution-jolts-Arab-world.aspx|work=[[Agence France Presse]] |publisher=Ahram Online |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=15 January 2011}} Tunisian philosopher [[Youssef Seddik (philosopher)|Youssef Seddik]] deemed the term inappropriate because the violence that accompanied the event was "perhaps as deep as [[Bastille Day]],"{{cite web |url=http://www.sudouest.fr/2011/01/16/une-prise-de-la-bastille-291463-652.php |title=Tunisie : " Une prise de la Bastille " |author=Bruno BÃ©ziat |date=16 January 2011 |work=Sud Ouest|publisher=|accessdate=17 January 2011}} and although the term was coined by the Tunisian journalist Zied El Hani, who first used it on his blog on 13 January and initially spread via social media such as Facebook (hence "Revolution Facebook" amongst the youth of Tunisia),{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2011/01/17/revolution-du-jasmin-une-expression-qui-ne-fait-pas-l-unanimite_1466871_3212.html |title="RÃ©volution du jasmin" : une expression qui ne fait pas l'unanimitÃ© |publisher=Le Monde |date=17 January 2011 |accessdate=30 March 2011}} it is not in widespread use in Tunisia itself. The lack of coverage in the domestic state-controlled media was criticised. Writer/activist [[Jillian York]] alleged that the [[mainstream media]], particularly in the Western world, was providing less coverage and less sympathetic coverage to the Tunisia protests relative to Iranian protests and the [[Iranian Green Movement|Green movement]] and China's censorship. York alleged the "US governmentâwhich intervened heavily in Iran, approving circumvention technology for export and famously asking Twitter to halt updates during a critical time periodâhas not made any public overtures toward Tunisia at this time."{{cite web|author=Jillian York |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/01/20111981222719974.html |title=Activist crackdown: Tunisia vs Iran â Opinion |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=9 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} Despite criticism about the "sparse" level of coverage and "little interest" given to the demonstrations by the international media, the protests have been hailed by some commentators as "momentous events" in Tunisian history. [[Brian Whitaker]], writing in ''[[The Guardian]]'', suggested on 28 December 2010, that the protests would be enough to bring an end to Ben Ali's presidency and noted similarities with the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989|protests]] that led to the end of [[Nicolae CeauÅescu]]'s reign in [[Romania]] in 1989,{{Cite news|author=Whitaker, Brian|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2010/dec/28/tunisia-ben-ali|title=How a man setting fire to himself sparked an uprising in Tunisia|date=28 December 2010|work=The Guardian |location=UK|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|accessdate=28 December 2010}} although Steven Cook, writing for the [[Council of Foreign Relations]], notes that a [[Tipping point (sociology)|tipping point]] is only obvious after the fact, and points to the counter-example of the [[2009-2010 Iranian election protests]].{{cite web|url=http://blogs.cfr.org/cook/2011/01/06/the-last-days-of-ben-ali/ |title=The Last Days of Ben Ali? |publisher=Steven Cook's Blog |date=6 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} Ben Ali's governing strategy was nevertheless regarded to be in serious trouble, and [[Elliot Abrams]] noted both that demonstrators were able for the first time at the end of 2010 to defy the security forces and that the regime had no obvious successors outside of Ben Ali's own family.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.cfr.org/abrams/2011/01/07/is-tunisia-next/ |title=Is Tunisia Next?
