|publisher=Elliott Abrams: Pressure Points |date=7 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2011}} The French management of the crisis came under severe criticism{{cite web|url=http://www.lepost.fr/article/2011/01/15/2371842_la-calamiteuse-gestion-de-la-crise-tunisienne-par-la-diplomatie-francaise.html |title=La calamiteuse gestion de la crise tunisienne par la diplomatie franÃ§aise â calvero sur |publisher=Lepost.fr |date=|accessdate=26 January 2011}} with notable silence in the mainstream media in the run-up to the crisis in its former colony.{{cite web|first=Mohamed |last=ElGohary |url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/01/16/france-our-embarassing-ex-friend-monsieur-ben-ali/?utm_source=twitterfeed&utm_medium=facebook |title=France: Our Embarrassing Ex Friend, Monsieur Ben Ali |publisher=Global Voices |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} ==Repercussion analysis== ''[[Al Jazeera]]'' read the ousting of the president as the "glass ceiling of fear has been for ever shattered in Tunisia and that the police state that Ben Ali created in 1987 when he came to power in a coup seems to be disintegrating." Though it added that Ben Ali's resignation following his statement that he had been "duped by his entourage" may not entirely be sincere just yet. ''[[Le Monde]]'' criticised French President Nicolas Sarkozy and the European Union's "Silence over the Tragedy" when the unrest broke.{{cite web|author=Hashem Ahelbarra |url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/2011/01/14/tunisia-end-era |title=Tunisia: The end of an era | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=|accessdate=15 January 2011}} The ''[[Christian Science Monitor]]'' suggested that [[mobile telecommunications]] played an influential role in the "revolution."{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Africa/Africa-Monitor/2011/0115/Tunisia-s-Jasmine-Revolution-and-how-mobile-phones-helped-it-happen |title=Tunisia's Jasmine Revolution, and how mobile phones helped it happen |publisher=Christian Science Monitor |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} The revolt in Tunisia began speculation that the Tunisian "Jasmine Revolution" would lead to protests against the multiple other autocratic regimes across the [[Arab world]]. This was most famously captured in the phrase asking whether ''"Tunisia is the Arab [[GdaÅsk]]?''. The allusion refers to the Polish [[Solidarity (Polish trade union)|Solidarity movement]] and [[GdaÅsk]]'s role as the birthplace of the movement that [[Collapse of Communism|ousted Communism in Eastern Europe]]. The phrase appeared in outlets such as the [[BBC]],{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/today/hi/today/newsid_9362000/9362677.stm |title=Today â Is this the 'Arab world's Gdansk?' |publisher=BBC News |date=15 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} as well as editorials by well known columnists [[Rami George Khouri|Rami Khouri]]{{cite web|url=http://mondoweiss.net/2011/01/khouri-tunisia-is-gdansk-shipyard-of-80-with-jazeera-as-megaphone-to-other-arab-countries.html |title=Khouri: Tunisia is Gdansk shipyard of â80 with Jazeera as megaphone to other Arab countries! |publisher=Mondoweiss.net |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} and [[Roger Cohen]].{{Cite news | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/18/opinion/18iht-edcohen18.html | title = The Arab Gdansk | accessdate=28 January 2011 | author=Roger Cohen |work=New York Times | date=17 January 2011}} [[Larbi Sadiki]] suggested that despite "conventional wisdom has it that 'terror' in the Arab world is monopolised by al-Qaeda in its various incarnations" there was also the practice of "regimes in countries like Tunisia and Algeria [that] have been arming and training security apparatuses to fight Osama bin Laden [they] were [also] caught unawares by the 'bin Laden within': the terror of marginalisation for the millions of educated youth who make up a large portion of the region's population. The winds of uncertainty blowing in the Arab west â the Maghreb â threaten to blow eastwards towards the [[Levant]] as the marginalised issue the fatalistic scream of despair to be given freedom and bread or death."{{cite web|author=Larbi Sadiki |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/01/201111413424337867.html |title=The 'bin Laden' of marginalisation â Opinion |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=|accessdate=15 January 2011}} A similar [[op-ed]] in ''Al Jazeera'' by [[Lamis Ardoni]] said that the protests had "brought down the walls of fear, erected by repression and marginalisation, thus restoring the Arab peoples' faith in their ability to demand social justice and end tyranny." He also said that the protests that succeeded in toppling the leadership should serve as a "warning to all leaders, whether supported by international or regional powers, that they are no longer immune to popular outcries of fury" even though Tunisia's ostensible change "could still be contained or confiscated by the country's ruling elite, which is desperately clinging to power." He called the protests the "Tunisian [[wikt:intifada|intifada"]] which had "placed the Arab world at a crossroads." He further added that if the change was ultimately successful in Tunisia it could "push the door wide open to freedom in Arab word. If it suffers a setback we shall witness unprecedented repression by rulers struggling to maintain their absolute grip on power. Either way, a system that combined a starkly unequal distribution of wealth with the denial of freedoms has collapsed."{{cite web|author=Lamis Andoni |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/01/2011115135046129936.html |title=To the tyrants of the Arab world... |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} Similarly, [[Mark LeVine]] noted that the events in Tunisia could spiral into the rest of the [[Arab world]] as the movement was "inspiring people...to take to the streets and warn their own sclerotic and autocratic leaders that they could soon face a similar fate." He then cited solidarity protests in Egypt where protesters chanted "Kefaya" and "We are next, we are next, Ben Ali tell Mubarak he is next;" and that Arab bloggers were supporting the movement in Tunisia as "the African revolution commencing...the global anti-capitalist revolution." He pointed to an article in ''[[al-Nahar]]'' that talked of an "inhuman globalisation" that had been imposed on the Arab world, however a "human" nationalism had not taken place. LeVine then accused the Obama administration in the United States of double standards when Clinton was in the region meeting with political and civil society leaders, however she responded to a question about the protests saying "We can't take sides," which was read as a failure to seize the "reigns of history" and "usher in a new era" to "defeat the forces of extremism" without the violent conflict in the Afghanistan-Pakistan area. Pointing out Clinton's remarks about regimes whose "foundations are sinking into the sand" and needed "reform", LeVine argued that US foreign policy in the Middle East and the [[ummah|Muslim world]] was "equally in danger of sinking into the sands if the President and his senior officials are not willing to get ahead of history's suddenly accelerating curve." He added, "It is the US and Europe, as much as the leaders of the region, who in Clinton's words are in need of 'a real vision for that future.'" Finally he said there were two scenarios that could play out: "a greater democratic opening across the Arab world," or a similar situation to Algeria in the early 1990s when the [[Algerian legislative election, 1991|democratic election]] was annulled and the Algeria went into a [[Algerian Civil War|civil war]].{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/01/20111167156465567.html|title=Tunisia: How the US got it wrong}} [[Robert Fisk]] asked if this was "The end of the age of dictators in the Arab world?" and partly answered the question in saying that Arab leaders would be "shaking in their boots." He also pointed out that the "despot" Ben Ali sought refuge in the same place as the ousted [[Idi Amin]] of [[Uganda]] and that "the French and the Germans and the Brits, dare we mention this, always praised the dictator for being a 'friend' of civilised Europe, keeping a firm hand on all those Islamists." He notably pointed at the "demographic explosion of youth" of the Maghreb, though he said that the change brought about in Tunisia may not last as: "For I fear this is going to be the same old story. Yes, we would like a democracy in Tunisia â but not too much democracy. Remember how we wanted Algeria to have a democracy back in the early Nineties? Then when it looked like the Islamists might win the second round of voting, we supported its military-backed government in suspending elections and crushing the Islamists and initiating a civil war in which 150,000 died. No, in the Arab world, we want law and order and stability." He added that "If it can happen in the holiday destination Tunisia, it can happen anywhere, can't it?"{{Cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/fisk/the-brutal-truth-about-tunisia-2186287.html|title=The brutal truth about Tunisia|publisher=The Independent | location=London|first=Robert|last=Fisk|date=17 January 2011}} Blake Hounshell wrote on Foreign Policy.com that the Tunisian precedent raised the prospect of a "new trend. There is something horrifying and, in a way, moving about these suicide attempts. It's a shocking, desperate tactic that instantly attracts attention, revulsion, but also sympathy."{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} ===Impact of the internet=== {{see|Human impact of Internet use#Internet and political revolutions}} The use of communication technologies, and the Internet in particular, has been widely credited as contributor to the mobilisation of protests.[http://www.wired.com/threatlevel/ Threat Level] A blog associated with ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' described the intricate efforts of the Tunisian authorities to control such online media as{{cite web|url=http://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/01/tunisia/|title=Tweeting Tyrants Out of Tunisia: Global Internet at Its Best|publisher=Threat Level / Wired}} Twitter and Facebook. Other regional regimes were also on higher alert to contain spillover effects that may ensue. On 11 March 2011, [[Reporters Without Borders]] gave its annual award for online media freedom to the Tunisian blogging group Nawaat.org. Founded in 2004, it played an important role rallying anti-government protesters by reporting on the protests which the national media ignored.[http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jn6P6Y2M4esLbvifHY0Foqb2vQTA?docId=361d3296b81a471bbfffeccbe1202202 Tunisian bloggers win online media award], [[Associated Press|AP]], 11 March 2011 changes are coming. ==Regional instability== {{main|Arab Spring}} {{see also|Mohamed Bouazizi#Copycat incidents}} [[Image:Hosni Mubarak facing the Tunisia domino effect.png|thumb|A [[political cartoon]] by [[Carlos Latuff]] depicting President of Egypt [[Hosni Mubarak]] facing the Tunisian knock-on [[domino theory|domino]] effect]] Bouazizi's actions have resonated across the region "There is great interest. The Egyptian people and the Egyptian public have been following the events in Tunisia with so much joy, since they can draw parallels between the Tunisian situation and their own."{{Cite news|last=Westcott |first=Kathryn |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-12206551 |title=Why do people set themselves on fire? |publisher=BBC News |date=18 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} An economic analyst also suggested instability could spread to [[Libya]] and [[Saudi Arabia]].[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/crude-oil-climbs-from-eight-week-low-in-new-york-as-u-s-economy-expands.html Oil Rises Most Since 2009 on Concern Egyptian Unrest to Spread] Bloomberg, 28 January 2011 An analyst on [[Al Jazeera]] added [[Algeria]] as well and cited Western concerns as their intelligence bureaus base large parts of their Arab networks in Tunisia.Breaking News. Al Jazeera English. 28 January 2010. 11:30 Egypt time. However, a financial analyst in [[Dubai]] suggested that "the spillover effect of the political turbulence to the large countries in the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]] is non-existent as there are no similar driver."{{cite web|last=Hankir |first=Zahra |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-30/dubai-shares-plunge-most-in-year-lead-gulf-drop-on-egypt-risk-protests.html |title=Dubai Shares Fall Most Since May on Egypt Unrest, Pacing Mideast Decline |publisher=Bloomberg |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}} After the beginning of the uprising in Tunisia, similar protests took place in almost all Arab countries from [[Morocco]] to [[Iraq]], as well as in other states, ranging from [[Gabon]] to [[Albania]], Iran, [[Kazakhstan]], and [[People's Republic of China|China]]. Following [[2011 Egyptian revolution|weeks of protests]], Egyptian president [[Hosni Mubarak]] resigned on 11 February. Major protests against longtime [[Libya]]n leader [[Muammar Gaddafi]] broke out on 17 February and quickly deteriorated into [[2011 Libyan civil war|civil war]], ultimately resulting in the downfall of the Gaddafi regime later in the year. In addition, [[2011 Yemeni protests|Yemen]], [[2011 Bahraini protests|Bahrain]], and [[2011 Algerian protests|Algeria]] saw major protests. ==See also== {{Portal box|Tunisia|Human rights}} * [[Arab Spring]] * [[History of Tunisia]] * [[List of conflicts in Africa]] * [[List of modern conflicts in North Africa]] * [[Operation Tunisia]] * [[Mohammed Bouazizi]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
